ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
You learn solidworks and some MATLAB - very little matlab.

You get a really good intro with Solidworks and the different simulation studies you can do.
Rudimentary basics of CAD
Basics of Solidworks.
2D sketching, perspective, 3D modeling, matlab, common mechanical parts and mechanisms, simulation tools (static and CFD)
It's an introduction to solidworks.
This course gave me my first formal exposure to SolidWorks through various design projects
I learned how to CAD model in Solidworks and also gained some familiarity with using MATLAB for various tasks such as coordinate projections.
Learn how to use SolidWorks and included simulation packages as well as some MATLAB. For final project, you can choose to use other CAD softwares youre familiar with.
I was gained engineering design skills with the help of computers and software.
SOLIDWORKS.and computer aided design generally
I gained foundational knowledge into how Solidworks and CAD tools in general work.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of the course is that you get out however much you put it. You could coast in the course and get a fine grade however you will not learn much. This course really depends on the 'user'.

Strengths: very hands-on and project based
Weaknesses: not much actual teaching, essentially you self-teach yourself from youtube tutorials and experimentation

Strengths: super flexible

Weaknesses: not very engaging and could be learned with just youtube tutorials

The course is mastery-based which means you can redo assignments as many times as you need to get the skill down which is (I think) the only way to teach CAE. The course also meaningfully covers all aspects of CAE, not just CAD.

I liked that the workload was low. I think class time could've been used more effectively (e.g., less lecture and more of the solidworks built-in tutorials would've been useful). Professor Freeman sometimes didn't know the answers to my solidworks questions.

Only strengths! I loved how this course was so self-paced and project-focused. Dr. Freeman did a great job of making the class chill yet productive. I feel that the gentle pace allowed me to gain a better understanding of how to use Solidworks and finalize my projects rather than a rushed final product.

Strengths: Prof. Freeman is has an in-depth knowledge of SolidWorks and more importantly understands how to convey it. Learning through practice (as opposed to just lectures) is emphasized so students actually leave with a firm understanding of the software.

Weaknesses: in terms of logistics, it is sometimes difficult to know when assignments are due and what the criteria for completion are because the canvas pages isnt updated regularly, but the professor is very understanding so not a huge deal.
I think the course could include additive production engineering methods such as 3D printing with practical work on it.
Great difference between those who already have experience with the software and those who are beginners.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Super chill and a great way to learn Solidworks
Yeah if they want to learn solidworks at a defined pace.

Yes, if you are looking for a gut MENG elective or just a gut engineering elective. Honestly, I really enjoyed getting to mess around in CAD, and it was nice to have one engineering course that didn't take up a shit ton of my time. You essentially can just do all the assignments in class, the only time I had to do outside work was for the final project, and that was only a couple hours. However, if you are looking to actually become very proficient in CAD and design complex structures, you are probably better off just self-teaching. You will learn the basics of how to design parts and perform very very simple motion studies and FEAs, but you will probably learn more CAD doing a self-directed project for a club or another class than in this class. Definitely would recommend for all MENG majors though just to get a little more CAD experience and to have one chill class (we be struggling out here)
Yeah, its a fun easy engineering course. Workload is extremely low.

If you are interesting in learning CAD or even just expanding your skills and adding more to your CAE toolkit, you should take this course. It's an easy course that actually teaches useful skills for engineers.

It's a low-workload MENG elective. If you already sort-of know how to use solidworks, you probably won't get much out of the course unless you take it upon yourself to learn more advanced things, but it's still good practice.
Yes! Great way to learn CAD at a slower pace. The grading scheme of submit until you get it right is also great to facilitate learning in a non-stressful way

I would recommend this course to ANY engineering major!! It's a great way to learn about CAD without high-pressure deadlines or assignments, and the course structure rewards you for trying to explore other elements of CAD outside of the curriculum.

If you are an engineering student, this course is a must take as SolidWorks is a fundamental software in the field. 

For anyone outside engineering, take this course if you are interested in learning to work with computer models / 3D printing and are willing to put in time to get comfortable with the program outside of class.

Yes, I course is well suited for students with diverse backgrounds and helps them develop designing skills through the use of software. Students without a background in mechanical engineering can take this course successfully.
I think it's good just to review and know how to do some more specific operations in Solidworks
